title: R45809
content: Critical infrastructure (CI) encompasses machinery, facilities, and information crucial for governance, public health, and the economy. Adverse events can result from disruptions to CI systems, whether due to natural disasters or deliberate attacks. This report outlines key policy concerns for Congress, including defining and identifying CI, assessing CI risk, federal organization for CI, and the role of the private sector. Presidential Decision Directive 63 (PDD-63) in 1998 was the first policy guidance on critical infrastructure protection, emphasizing national vulnerability to asymmetric attacks and the interdependence of economic and military power on CI. Presidential Decision Directive 63 (PDD-63) in 1998 defined critical infrastructure as essential systems for the economy and government. It aimed to eliminate national vulnerability to cyber or physical attacks. However, assessing the criticality of specific assets has proven challenging due to the complexity and interconnectedness of infrastructure systems. For example, the U.S. electricity sub-sector alone has nearly 7,000 operational power plants. Critical infrastructure, as defined by the USA PATRIOT Act of 2001, includes systems and assets vital to national security, economic security, public health, and safety. The focus has expanded to include essential services and public conveniences, with an increased concern for threats posed by state and asymmetric actors. The intelligence community has expanded its focus on asymmetric threats to critical infrastructure (CI) posed by state and non-state adversaries. Asymmetric attacks, using physical or cyber means, aim to damage or disrupt domestic CI systems and assets. Policy now includes infrastructure-related events with disruptive effects, emphasizing infrastructure as vital for prosperity, public safety, and civic well-being. The National Infrastructure Protection Plan (NIPP) defines critical infrastructure as assets that support American society and considers impacts of natural and manmade hazards at various levels. CI policy has evolved to focus on society-centric resilience over asset protection, with U.S. election systems designated as critical infrastructure in 2017. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) designated U.S. election systems as critical infrastructure, including physical locations and technology infrastructure. This designation is part of the 16 critical infrastructure sectors outlined in Presidential Policy Directive 21 (PPD-21) and the 2013 NIPP. The federal government utilizes these sectors for voluntary public-private partnerships to enhance security and resilience. The critical infrastructure sectors, designated by DHS, involve public-private partnerships with various federal agencies playing leading roles. Each sector has formal coordination bodies representing private sector stakeholders and SLTT governments. There is no single, consistently applied definition of critical infrastructure, reflecting the evolving interests and perspectives of different constituencies. This variation in definitions is not just a matter of semantics but reflects negotiations on congressional responsibility, government programs, and public-private sector relationships. Critical infrastructure policy has two orientations, critical infrastructure protection (CIP), emphasizing the protection of critical systems and assets. Critical infrastructure protection (CIP) focuses on identifying and protecting infrastructure assets based on the consequences of their loss or disruption. Critical infrastructure resilience (CIR) emphasizes investments in hazard mitigation and preparedness to ensure availability of essential services during emergencies. Policy in developed countries now leans towards system resilience over asset protection, following major legislation post-9/11 attacks. In the United States and other developed countries, policy practice has shifted towards system resilience over asset protection in critical infrastructure security. Federal organization for critical infrastructure (CI) issues has evolved in response to threats, with three distinct periods of development: policy initiatives in the late 1990s, post-9/11 reorganization, and transition to an all-hazards resilience framework. Congressional funding priorities and program guidance play a role in supporting national CI security goals. The Clinton Administration established the Commission on Critical Infrastructure Protection in 1996 to address emerging cyber threats. PDD-63, issued two years later, required the government to eliminate vulnerabilities to cyber or physical attacks within five years. The directive focused on increasing interagency coordination through the National Coordinator for Security, Infrastructure Protection, and Counter-Terrorism. The Gilmore Commission, chartered by Congress in 1999, found that implementation of PDD-63 was incomplete. The National Coordinator for Security, Infrastructure Protection, and Counterterrorism lacked program and budget authority, and there was no overall national CIP strategy in place. The Information Sharing and Analysis Centers (ISACs) were still in early stages of development. The 9/11 attacks prompted urgent national concern for critical infrastructure protection. Two legislative tracks emerged, one favoring the reestablishment of the Office of Homeland Security with enhanced coordination and oversight, following the Gilmore Commission's recommendations. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 reflected the recommendations of the Hart-Rudman Commission for comprehensive consolidation of government counterterrorism functions under a single federal agency, the National Homeland Security Agency. This aimed to ensure clearer lines of executive authority, centralization of relevant counterterrorism functions, and better interagency coordination to protect against terrorist attacks. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 transferred infrastructure security functions to DHS, incorporating nearly three dozen federal agencies into four major directorates.
